senses.definition: to treat food or tobacco with smoke, salt or heat, etc. in order to preserve it

examples.x: cured ham/bacon

senses.definition: to connect to a service or computer system using a phone line

examples.x: Remote users dial in from various locations worldwide.
The campaigners and volunteers dial into a conference call every Wednesday.

senses.definition: to direct all your effort and attention on to what you are trying to achieve, so you perform as well as you can

examples.x: I think Szabo has been the key player so far. She's dialled in.
Fassbender eventually dialled into the character of Macbeth when he got a new insight on his motivation.

senses.definition: to connect to a service or computer system using a phone line

examples.x: Remote users dial in from various locations worldwide.
The campaigners and volunteers dial into a conference call every Wednesday.

senses.definition: to direct all your effort and attention on to what you are trying to achieve, so you perform as well as you can

examples.x: I think Szabo has been the key player so far. She's dialled in.
Fassbender eventually dialled into the character of Macbeth when he got a new insight on his motivation.

senses.definition: to put something quickly into a liquid and take it out again

examples.x: He dipped the brush into the paint.
Dip your hand in to see how hot the water is.
The fruit had been dipped in chocolate.

senses.definition: to go downwards or to a lower level; to make something do this

examples.x: The sun dipped below the horizon.
Sales for this quarter have dipped from 38.7 million to 33 million.
The road dipped suddenly as we approached the town.
The plane dipped its wings.

senses.definition: if you dip your headlights when driving a car at night, you make the light from them point down so that other drivers do not have the light in their eyes dip
when farmers dip animals, especially sheep, they put them in a bath of a liquid containing chemicals in order to kill insects, etc. dip
to get rid of somebody/something that you do not want or cannot keep

examples.x: the difficulties of disposing of nuclear waste
to dispose of stolen property
Radioactive waste must be disposed of safely.

senses.definition: to deal with a problem, question or threat successfully

examples.x: That seems to have disposed of most of their arguments.

senses.definition: to defeat or kill somebody

examples.x: It took her a mere 20 minutes to dispose of her opponent.

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between two people or things

examples.x: At what age are children able to distinguish between right and wrong?
English law clearly distinguishes between murder and manslaughter.
It was hard to distinguish one twin from the other.
Sometimes reality and fantasy are hard to distinguish.
We can distinguish five meanings of the word ‘mad’.

senses.definition: to be a characteristic that makes two people, animals or things different

examples.x: What was it that distinguished her from her classmates?
The male bird is distinguished from the female by its red beak.
The adult bird can be readily distinguished by its orange bill.
Does your cat have any distinguishing marks?
The power of speech distinguishes human beings from animals.

senses.definition: to be able to see or hear something

examples.x: I could not distinguish her words, but she sounded agitated.
She could not distinguish the make and colour of the car in the fading light.

senses.definition: to do something so well that people notice and admire you

examples.x: She has already distinguished herself as an athlete.

senses.definition: very successful and admired by other people

examples.x: He has had a long and distinguished career in medicine.

senses.definition: having an appearance that makes somebody look important or that makes people admire or respect them

examples.x: I think grey hair makes you look very distinguished.

senses.definition: the act of developing a wider range of products, interests, skills, etc. in order to be more successful or reduce risk

examples.x: the company's diversification into healthcare products

senses.definition: the process of changing so that there is greater variety

examples.x: the evolutionary diversification of flowering plants

senses.definition: to develop a wider range of products, interests, skills, etc. in order to be more successful or reduce risk

examples.x: Farmers are being encouraged to diversify into new crops.
The company has been trying to diversify its business.

senses.definition: to change or to make something change so that there is greater variety

examples.x: Patterns of family life are diversifying.
The culture has been diversified with the arrival of immigrants.

senses.definition: used to refer to actions that you do not mention by name or do not know about

examples.x: What are you doing this evening?
We will do what we can to help.
Are you doing anything tomorrow evening?
The company ought to do something about the poor service.
What have you done to your hair?
There's nothing to do (= no means of passing the time in an enjoyable way) in this place.
There's nothing we can do about it (= we can't change the situation).
What can I do for you (= how can I help)?

senses.definition: to act or behave in the way mentioned

examples.x: Do as you're told!
They are free to do as they please.
You would do well to (= I advise you to) consider all the options before buying.

senses.definition: used to ask or talk about the success or progress of somebody/something

examples.x: How is the business doing?
She did well out of (= made a big profit from) the deal.
He's doing very well at school (= his work is good).
Both mother and baby are doing well (= after the birth of the baby).
How are you doing (= how are you)?

senses.definition: to work at or perform an activity or a task

examples.x: I'm doing some research on the subject.
I have a number of things to do today.
I do aerobics once a week.
Let's do (= meet for) lunch.
Sorry. I don't do funny (= I can't be funny).

senses.definition: to perform the activity or task mentioned wash the dishes

examples.cf: do the ironing, cooking, shopping, etc.
examples.x: I like listening to the radio when I'm doing the ironing.
You could help me by doing the dishes.

examples.cf: do some, a little, etc. acting, writing, etc.
examples.x: She did a lot of acting when she was at college.

senses.definition: used with nouns to talk about tasks such as cleaning, washing, arranging, etc.

examples.x: to do (= wash) the dishes
to do (= arrange) the flowers
I like the way you've done your hair.

senses.definition: to work at something as a job

examples.x: What do you do (= what is your job)?
What does she want to do when she leaves school?
What did she do for a living?
What's Tom doing these days?

senses.definition: to learn or study something

examples.x: I'm doing physics, biology and chemistry.
Have you done any (= studied anything by) Keats?

senses.definition: to find the answer to something; to solve something

examples.x: I can't do this sum.
Are you good at doing crosswords?

senses.definition: to produce, make or provide something make

examples.x: to do a drawing/painting/sketch
Does this pub do lunches?
Who's doing the food for the wedding reception?
Many hotels don't do single rooms at all.
I'll do a copy for you.
I'll do you a copy.

senses.definition: to be suitable or be enough for somebody/something

examples.x: ‘Can you lend me some money?’ ‘Sure—will $20 do?’
These shoes won't do for the party.
The box will do fine as a table.
This room will do me nicely, thank you (= it has everything I need).

senses.definition: to perform or produce a play, an opera, etc.

examples.x: The local dramatic society is doing ‘Hamlet’ next month.

senses.definition: to copy somebody’s behaviour or the way somebody speaks, sings, etc., especially in order to make people laugh

examples.x: He does a great Elvis Presley.

senses.definition: to finish something

examples.x: Sit there and wait till I'm done.
I've done talking—let's get started.
Did you get your article done in time?

senses.definition: to travel a particular distance

examples.x: How many miles did you do during your tour?
My car does 40 miles to the gallon (= uses one gallon of petrol to travel 40 miles).

senses.definition: to complete a journey

examples.x: We did the round trip in two hours.

senses.definition: to travel at or reach a particular speed

examples.x: The car was doing 90 miles an hour.

senses.definition: to visit a place as a tourist

examples.x: We did Tokyo in three days.

senses.definition: to spend a period of time doing something

examples.x: She did a year at college, but then dropped out.
He did six years (= in prison) for armed robbery.

senses.definition: to deal with or attend to somebody/something

examples.x: The hairdresser said she could do me (= cut my hair) at three.

senses.definition: to cook something

examples.x: How would you like your steak done?

senses.definition: to cheat somebody

examples.x: This isn't a genuine antique—you've been done.

senses.definition: to punish somebody

examples.x: They did him for tax evasion.

senses.definition: to steal from a place

examples.x: The gang did a warehouse and a supermarket.

senses.definition: to take an illegal drug

examples.x: He doesn't smoke, drink or do drugs.

senses.definition: to have sex with somebody
to move quickly and suddenly to one side in order to avoid somebody/something

examples.x: He ran across the road, dodging the traffic.
The girl dodged behind a tree to hide from the other children.

senses.definition: to avoid doing something, especially in a dishonest way

examples.x: He dodged his military service.
Claims that he dodged the draft for the Vietnam War could damage his election chances.
She tried to dodge paying her taxes.

senses.definition: the most excellent thing or person

examples.x: We all want the best for our children.
They only buy the best.
They're all good players, but she's the best of all.
We're the best of friends (= very close friends).

senses.definition: the highest standard that somebody/something can reach

examples.x: She always brings out the best in people.
The town looks its best (= is most attractive) in the spring.
Don't worry about the exam—just do your best.
The roses are past their best now.
I don't really feel at my best today.

senses.definition: something that is as close as possible to what you need or want

examples.x: Fifty pounds is the best I can offer you.
The best we can hope for in the game is a draw.

senses.definition: the highest standard that a particular person has reached, especially in a sport

examples.x: a lifetime best of 12.0 seconds

senses.definition: to say numbers in the correct order

examples.x: Billy can't count yet.
She can count up to 10 in Italian.
to count from 1 to 10

senses.definition: to calculate the total number of people, things, etc. in a particular group

examples.x: They're still counting votes in Texas.

senses.definition: to include somebody/something when you calculate a total

examples.x: We have invited 50 people, not counting the children.

senses.definition: to be important

examples.x: It is going to be a close election, so every vote counts.

senses.definition: to be officially accepted; to accept something officially

examples.x: Don't go over that line or your throw won't count.

to look for/find a job

to leave/quit your job

a temporary/permanent job
a summer/Saturday/holiday/vacation job

one of the people under consideration for the job of managing director

senses.definition: a particular task or piece of work that you have to do

examples.x: He said he wouldn't do it because it wasn't his job.

examples.x: a bank job

an inside job (= done by somebody in the organization where the crime happens)

senses.definition: a particular kind of thing

examples.x: It's real wood—not one of those plastic jobs.

senses.definition: an item of work that is done by a computer as a single unit

examples.x: The job can be processed overnight.

senses.definition: something that you do to make somebody believe something that is not true, or to annoy somebody as a joke

examples.x: They had to think of a trick to get past the guards.

a magic trick

senses.definition: a way of doing something that works well; a good method

senses.definition: the cards that you play or win in a single part of a card game

senses.definition: having a flat surface that does not slope

senses.definition: not showing any emotion; steady

examples.x: Add the lemon juice and mix well.

examples.x: He was driving at well over the speed limit.

a well-loved tale

He liked her well enough (= to a reasonable degree) but he wasn't going to make a close friend of her.

examples.x: She could well afford to pay for it herself.

senses.definition: with good reason

examples.x: I can't very well leave now.

senses.definition: a series of images, events and feelings that happen in your mind while you are asleep

examples.x: I had a really weird dream last night.

a vivid dream about my old school.

examples.x: She walked around in a dream all day.

senses.definition: a beautiful or wonderful person or thing

examples.x: Did I talk in my sleep? I must have been dreaming.
I dreamed about you last night.

examples.x: Let's go for a drive.

senses.definition: power from the engine of a vehicle that is transferred to the wheels

examples.x: Both models feature an electric motor that sends drive to the rear wheels.

senses.definition: the position of the gears in a car with automatic transmission (= a system that changes the gears by itself so the driver does not have to) in which they are unlocked so that the engine can send power to the wheels

examples.x: He jumped in, put the car in drive and set off.

senses.definition: a wide hard path or a private road that leads from the street to a house

examples.x: There were two cars parked in the drive.

examples.x: The company is launching a big recruitment drive.
an export/economy drive
a drive for greater efficiency

senses.definition: a strong desire or need in people

examples.x: The treatment should not affect your sex drive or fertility.

senses.definition: a strong desire to do things and achieve something; great energy

examples.x: He'll do very well—he has tremendous drive.

senses.definition: a long hard hit or kick

examples.x: She has a strong forehand drive (= in tennis).

senses.definition: a type of computer storage that stores large amounts of data on a spinning (= turning) disk

examples.x: a CD drive

senses.definition: a social occasion when a lot of people compete in a game such as whist or bingo
an act of going after animals or the enemy and making them go into a smaller area, especially in order to kill or capture them
used in the names of roads

examples.x: 21 Island Heights Drive

senses.definition: determined to succeed, and working very hard to do so
influenced or caused by a particular thing

examples.x: a market-driven economy
a character-driven movie
supply-driven inflation

senses.definition: having a lot of energy and a strong personality

examples.x: a dynamic leader

senses.definition: always changing and making progress

examples.x: The business has managed to change and remain dynamic.

senses.definition: producing movement
describing an action rather than a state. Dynamic verbs (for example eat, grow, knock, die) can be used in the progressive tenses. Dynamic
energy and enthusiasm to make new things happen or to make things succeed -ism

examples.x: The freshness and dynamism of her approach was welcomed by all her students.

senses.definition: producing the result that is wanted or intended; producing a successful result

examples.x: Aspirin is a simple but highly effective treatment.

senses.definition: in reality, although not officially intended

examples.x: the effective, if not the actual, leader of the party

senses.definition: coming into use

examples.x: The new speed limit on this road becomes effective from 1 June.

senses.definition: in a way that produces the intended result or a successful result

senses.definition: used when you are saying what the facts of a situation are

senses.definition: the fact of producing the result that is wanted or intended; the fact of producing a successful result

examples.x: to check the effectiveness of the security system

senses.definition: producing the result that was intended

examples.x: an effectual remedy

senses.definition: in a way that produces a particular result Effectually

examples.x: Napoleon's progress was effectually stopped by the deep Russian winter.

senses.definition: producing the result that was wanted or intended

examples.x: They hope the new drug will prove especially efficacious in the relief of pain.

senses.definition: an attempt to do something especially when it is difficult to do

examples.x: The project was a team effort.
a joint/collaborative effort
a determined/conscious/special effort

examples.cf: in an effort to do something
examples.x: The company has laid off 150 workers in an effort to save money.

senses.definition: the physical or mental energy that you need to do something; something that takes a lot of energy

examples.x: You should put more effort into your work.

senses.definition: a particular activity that a group of people organize in order to achieve something

examples.x: the European space effort
the United Nations’ peacekeeping effort

senses.definition: the result of an attempt to do something

examples.x: I'm afraid this essay is a poor effort.

senses.definition: a force applied by a machine or in a process
one of the awards given every year in the US for achievement in the making of television programmes Emmy
a person who is young and successful and whose behaviour and ideas may be unusual, causing people to be shocked or embarrassed
a company or business

senses.definition: a large project, especially one that is difficult

examples.x: Have you heard about his latest business enterprise?

senses.definition: the development of businesses by the people of a country rather than by the government

senses.definition: the ability to think of new projects and make them successful

senses.definition: having or showing the ability to think of new projects or new ways of doing things and make them successful Enterprising

senses.definition: the same in size, quantity, value, etc. as something else exactly

senses.definition: to capture a place or person; to get control of something

examples.x: The rebels succeeded in taking the town.

The rebels took him prisoner.

senses.definition: to choose, buy or rent something

examples.x: I'll take the grey jacket.

senses.definition: to buy a newspaper or magazine regularly

examples.x: We take the ‘Express’.

senses.definition: to accept or receive something

examples.x: If they offer me the job, I'll take it.

senses.definition: to act in response to an opportunity

examples.x: When the bus stopped for fuel, we took the opportunity to get something to eat.

senses.definition: to accept somebody as a customer, patient, etc.

examples.x: The school doesn't take boys (= only has girls).

senses.definition: to experience or be affected by something

examples.x: The school took the full force of the explosion.

senses.definition: to understand or consider something in a particular way

examples.x: How am I supposed to take that remark?

examples.x: Even the experts took the painting for a genuine Van Gogh.

senses.definition: to have a particular feeling, opinion or attitude

examples.x: My parents always took an interest in my hobbies.

examples.x: Take 5 from 12 and you're left with 7.

senses.definition: used to introduce somebody/something as an example

examples.x: Lots of couples have problems in the first year of marriage. Take Ann and Paul.

senses.definition: to have or start to have a particular form, position or state

examples.x: Our next class will take the form of a debate.

senses.definition: to need or require something in order to happen or be done

examples.x: It only takes one careless driver to cause an accident.

senses.definition: to use something in order to work

examples.x: The buses have been adapted to take biofuel.

senses.definition: to wear a particular size in shoes or clothes

examples.x: What size shoes do you take?

senses.definition: to have enough space for something/somebody; to be able to hold or contain a particular quantity

examples.x: The bus can take 60 passengers.

senses.definition: to be the teacher or leader in a class or a religious service

examples.x: The head teacher usually takes us for French.

senses.definition: to go over or around something

examples.x: The horse took the first fence well.

senses.definition: to kick or throw the ball from a fixed or agreed position

examples.x: to take a penalty/free kick/corner

senses.definition: to use a particular method to find out people’s opinions

examples.x: to take a vote/poll/survey

senses.definition: to be successful; to work

examples.x: The skin graft failed to take.

senses.definition: to have or require something when used in a sentence or other structure

examples.x: The verb ‘rely’ takes the preposition ‘on’.

senses.definition: the feeling that you have when you want to know or learn more about somebody/something

senses.definition: the quality that something has when it attracts somebody’s attention or makes them want to know more about it

senses.definition: an activity or a subject that you enjoy and that you spend time doing or studying interest

examples.x: Her main interests are music and tennis.

interest charges/payments

senses.definition: a share in a business or company and its profits

senses.definition: a connection with something that affects your attitude to it, especially because you may benefit from it in some way

senses.definition: a group of people who are in the same business or who share the same aims that they want to protect

senses.definition: a part near the edge of something; an area just beyond the edge of something

senses.definition: either the right or left part of a person’s body, from the armpit (= where the arm joins the body) to the hip (= where the leg joins the body)

senses.definition: used in adjectives to state the number or type of sides

senses.definition: a side dish (= a small amount of food, for example a salad, served with the main course of a meal)

senses.definition: one of the two halves of an animal that has been killed for meat

examples.x: What's on the other side?

examples.x: Your work is alright but I'm sure you could do better.

senses.definition: that can be allowed

examples.x: Are you sure it's alright for me to leave early?

senses.definition: used to emphasize that there is no doubt about something

examples.x: ‘Are you sure it's her?’ ‘Oh, it's her alright.’

senses.definition: used to show that you support or admire a leader, a nation, etc., or that you are pleased that they have been successful; an expression of worship to a god

examples.x: The whole crowd shouted ‘Jai Mahatma!’

senses.definition: to work well together; to form a successful group

examples.x: We just didn't jell as a group.

senses.definition: to become clearer and more definite; to work well

examples.x: Ideas were beginning to jell in my mind.
That day, everything jelled.

senses.definition: to become thicker and more solid; to form a gel
a feeling of great happiness pleasure

examples.x: Her books have brought joy to millions.
the joy of discovery
the sheer joy of being with her again
I almost wept with joy.
I didn't expect them to jump for joy at the news (= to be very pleased).
I danced for joy when I found out I was pregnant.
Tears of joy were running down his cheeks.
To his great joy, she accepted.
He spoke of his joy at the news.
her joy at scoring the winning goal
Their joy in life and enthusiasm for learning are infectious.
Her joy in playing the violin was obvious.

senses.definition: a person or thing that causes you to feel very happy

examples.x: the joys of fatherhood
The game was a joy to watch.

senses.definition: success or satisfaction

examples.x: We complained about our rooms but got no joy from the manager.
‘Any joy at the shops?’ ‘No, they didn't have what I wanted.’

senses.definition: feeling or showing great happiness because of a success Jubilant

examples.x: The fans were in jubilant mood after the victory.

senses.definition: a feeling of great happiness because of a success

examples.x: There were scenes of jubilation among her supporters.
their jubilation at reaching the final

senses.definition: to move quickly off the ground or away from a surface by pushing yourself with your legs and feet

examples.x: ‘Quick, jump!’ he shouted.
She jumped into the water to save them.
He jumped into the air and started cheering.
She jumped down from the chair.
The children were jumping up and down with excitement.
The pilot jumped from the burning plane (= with a parachute).
He killed himself by jumping off a bridge.
She has jumped 2.2 metres.

senses.definition: to pass over something by jumping

examples.x: He jumped over the wall to get away.
Can you jump that gate?
He jumped the stream and carried on up the hill.
His horse fell as it jumped the last hurdle.
I jumped my horse over all the fences.

senses.definition: to move quickly and suddenly

examples.x: He jumped to his feet when they called his name.
She jumped up and ran out of the room.
Do you want a ride? Jump in.
He jumped out of the car and disappeared into the building.
When she heard the news, she immediately jumped on a plane to France.

senses.definition: to make a sudden movement because of surprise, fear or excitement

examples.x: A loud bang made me jump.
Her heart jumped when she heard the news.

senses.definition: to rise suddenly by a large amount

examples.x: Prices jumped by 60% last year.
Sales jumped from $2.7 billion to $3.5 billion.
Your interest rate might suddenly jump at the end of the fixed period.
The FTSE 100 benchmark index jumped 199.9 points.

senses.definition: to change suddenly from one subject to another

examples.x: I couldn't follow the talk because he kept jumping about from one topic to another.
The story then jumps from her childhood in New York to her first visit to London.

senses.definition: to leave out something and pass to a further point or stage

examples.x: You seem to have jumped several steps in the argument.

senses.definition: to move suddenly and unexpectedly, especially out of the correct position

examples.x: The needle jumped across the dial.

senses.definition: to attack somebody suddenly

examples.x: The thieves jumped him in a dark alleyway.

senses.definition: to get on a vehicle very quickly, especially in a way that is dangerous or illegal

examples.x: to jump a train

senses.definition: to start the engine of a car by connecting the battery to the battery of another car with jump leads
to put a lot of energy into starting a process or an activity or into making it start more quickly
to be very lively

examples.x: The club's jumping tonight.

senses.definition: to try to have all the possessions and social achievements that your friends and neighbours have
powerful and aggressive

examples.x: the movie’s kick-ass heroine
his reputation as a kick-ass coach

senses.definition: extremely good and successful

examples.x: a kick-ass visual feast
truly kick-ass quality

senses.definition: to hit somebody/something with your foot

examples.x: Stop kicking—it hurts!
She was punched and kicked by her attackers.
The boys were kicking a ball around in the yard.
Vandals had kicked the door down.
She had to kick the door open because her hands were full.
She kicked at the loose pebbles by the roadside.

senses.definition: to move your legs as if you were kicking something

examples.x: The child was dragged away, kicking and screaming.
The dancers kicked their legs in the air.

senses.definition: to be annoyed with yourself because you have done something stupid, missed an opportunity, etc.

examples.x: He'll kick himself when he finds out he could have had the job.

senses.definition: to score points by kicking the ball

examples.x: to kick a penalty/goal
He kicked 23 points, ensuring victory for New Zealand.

senses.definition: to stop doing something harmful that you have done for a long time

examples.x: He had been smoking for 15 years and wanted to kick the habit.
to kick drugs/the booze

senses.definition: a quality that makes you determined to succeed or win at any cost

examples.x: The manager urged his players to find their killer instinct.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something die

examples.x: Cancer kills thousands of people every year.
Tiredness while driving can kill.
Dozens of civilians were killed or injured in the attack.
She was nearly killed by a car bomb.
Both members of the crew were killed instantly when the missile hit their aircraft.
Three soldiers were killed in action (= while fighting) yesterday.
She tried to kill me!
The terrorists threatened to kill the hostages.
I bought a spray to kill the weeds.
My mother will kill me (= be very angry with me) when she finds out.
He tried to kill himself with sleeping pills.
Don't kill yourself trying to get the work done by tomorrow. It can wait.

senses.definition: to destroy something or make it less good; to make something stop

examples.x: to kill a rumour
She claims that social media kills relationships.
The defeat last night killed the team's chances of qualifying.

senses.definition: to switch off a light or engine; to stop a computer program or process

examples.x: She killed the engine and climbed out.
The only way to kill the process is to reboot the computer.

senses.definition: to cause somebody pain

examples.x: My feet are killing me.

senses.definition: to make somebody laugh a lot

examples.x: Stop it! You're killing me!

senses.definition: the praise and honour that goes with a particular achievement or position

examples.x: the kudos of playing for such a famous team

senses.definition: special praise to somebody for something they have done

examples.x: Kudos to Bill for fixing that problem.
Special kudos goes to Patrick Stewart for his role as the captain.
You have to give her kudos for keeping it secret.

senses.definition: to come down through the air onto the ground or another surface

examples.x: The plane landed safely.
The flight is due to land at 3 o'clock.
Both aircraft landed on the runway.
A fly landed on his nose.

senses.definition: to control a plane and bring it down to the ground

examples.x: The pilot landed the plane safely.
to land a helicopter/an aircraft
He landed the damaged aircraft in a field.

senses.definition: to arrive somewhere in a plane or a boat

examples.x: We shall be landing shortly. Please fasten your seat belts.
The troops landed at dawn.
They were the first men to land on the moon.

senses.definition: to put somebody/something on land from an aircraft, a boat, etc.

examples.x: The troops were landed by helicopter.

senses.definition: to come down somewhere after jumping, falling or being thrown

examples.x: She fell and landed heavily on her back.
I landed awkwardly and twisted my ankle.
Several men were killed when rocket shells landed in the troop camp.
The heavy ball landed with a thud.
He came flying through the air and landed in a crumpled heap at my feet.

senses.definition: to arrive somewhere and cause difficulties that have to be dealt with

examples.x: Why do complaints always land on my desk (= why do I always have to deal with them)?

senses.definition: to succeed in getting a job, etc., especially one that a lot of other people want

examples.x: He's just landed a starring role in a Hollywood movie.
She's just landed herself a company directorship.

senses.definition: to catch a fish and bring it out of the water on to the land

examples.x: It took me three attempts to land the fish.

senses.definition: to score a penalty (4) or conversion (3)

examples.x: Ceri Sweeney landed a penalty with the last kick of the half.

senses.definition: used to describe a final attempt to achieve something, when there is not much hope of succeeding Last-ditch

examples.x: She underwent a heart transplant in a last-ditch attempt to save her.

senses.definition: done or achieved at the last possible moment Last-gasp

examples.x: a last-gasp 2–1 victory

senses.definition: deserving to be praised or admired, even if not really successful

examples.x: a laudable aim/attempt
It was a laudable attempt to end the stalemate in the talks.
Laudable though these aims are, they are not likely to succeed.

senses.definition: to make the sounds and movements of your face that show you think something is funny or silly cackle

examples.x: to laugh out loud
to laugh loudly/aloud/heartily
When I heard her excuse, I just laughed.
I was laughing so hard that I had tears running down my cheeks.
The show was hilarious—I couldn't stop laughing.
You never laugh at my jokes!
They were laughing hysterically about something he had said.
She always makes me laugh.
He burst out laughing (= suddenly started laughing).
She laughed to cover her nervousness.
I told him I was worried but he laughed scornfully.
She laughed and said, ‘You silly man!’
‘You're crazy!’ she laughed.

senses.definition: used to say that you are in a very good position, especially because you have done something successfully

examples.x: If we win the next game we'll be laughing.

senses.definition: a person who has been given an official honour or prize for something important they have achieved

examples.x: a Nobel laureate

senses.definition: a bush or tree with dark, smooth, shiny leaves that remain on the bush and stay green through the year

examples.x: a laurel hedge

senses.definition: honour and praise given to somebody because of something that they have achieved

examples.x: She won laurels for her first novel.

senses.definition: used to refer to somebody who improves or starts to be successful again after a period of failure Lazarus
most important or most successful

examples.x: a leading expert/authority/figure/member
a leading contender/candidate
a leading manufacturer/company/newspaper
the team's leading scorer for the past two seasons
the leading provider of telecommunications services in Denmark

The leading causes of death are heart disease and cancer.

senses.definition: ahead of others in a race or contest

examples.x: She started the last lap just behind the leading group.
These are the leading first-round scores.

senses.definition: an area of land in the country used for growing crops or keeping animals in, usually surrounded by a fence, etc. plant

examples.x: We had to walk across a ploughed field.
We camped in a field near the village.
People were working in the fields.
We saw golden fields of wheat.
He planted a field of beans.
a rice/wheat field
The house overlooks the sugar cane fields.

senses.definition: an area of land used for the purpose mentioned

examples.x: a landing field

senses.definition: a large area of land covered with the thing mentioned; an area from which the thing mentioned is obtained

examples.x: The territory is covered with snow, bare rock and ice fields.
the discovery of the oil and gas fields in the North Sea

senses.definition: an area of land used for playing a sport on

examples.x: a football/soccer/sports field
a baseball/cricket/rugby field
Every player on the field did their best today.
Players need discipline both on and off the field (= when they are playing and also in their free time).
There was huge excitement as the teams came onto the field.
Today they take the field (= go on to the field to play a game) against county champions Essex.

senses.definition: the team that is trying to catch the ball rather than hit it

examples.x: He took the ball early and hit it through a gap in the field.

senses.definition: all the people or animals competing in a particular sports event

examples.x: The strong field includes three world record holders.

senses.definition: an area of land where a battle is fought

examples.x: a medal for bravery in the field
to die on the field of battle
a field ambulance/kitchen

senses.definition: a particular subject or activity that somebody works in or is interested in

examples.x: Child development is such an interesting field.
Genetic science has developed dramatically since I entered the field 40 years ago.
All of them are experts in their chosen field.
He was awarded a Nobel Prize for his work in this field.
She works in the field of adult education.
I enjoy meeting people in other fields of business.
This discovery has opened up a whole new field of study.
‘How big was the bomb, if it did all that damage?’ ‘I don’t know. Not my field’ (= that is not one of the subjects I know about).

senses.definition: the fact of people doing practical work or study, rather than working in a library or laboratory

examples.x: a field study/experiment
field recordings/observations
Her findings were based on extensive field and laboratory work.
We then tested the questionnaire in field conditions.
tests carried out in the field

senses.definition: all the people or products competing in a particular area of business

examples.x: They lead the field in home entertainment systems.

senses.definition: an area within which the force mentioned has an effect

examples.x: the earth’s gravitational field
an electromagnetic field
Weak electric fields are emitted by all living organisms.

senses.definition: part of a record that is a separate item of data

examples.x: You will need to create separate fields for first name, surname and address.
the use of keys to move between fields

senses.definition: the thing that keeps something strong and healthy and is necessary for successful development

examples.x: Tourism is the lifeblood of the city.

senses.definition: a person’s blood, when it is thought of as the thing that is necessary for life

examples.x: The wound was draining the lifeblood from him.

senses.definition: the main purpose or activity in a person’s life, or their greatest achievement
to turn your eyes in a particular direction look

examples.x: Look closely and tell me what you see.
If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.
‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’
Look! I'm sure that's Jennifer Lawrence!
Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!
She looked at me and smiled.
I got up and looked out of the window.
She looked across to the other side of the room.

senses.definition: to try to find somebody/something

examples.x: Where have you been? We've been looking for you.
Are you still looking for a job?
We’re looking for someone with experience for this post.
They are always looking for ways to save money.
I can't find my book—I've looked everywhere.

senses.definition: to pay attention to something

examples.x: Look at the time! We're going to be late.
Can't you look where you're going?

senses.definition: to seem; to appear

examples.x: How do I look?
You look great!
The garden looks nice.
Don't worry—it looks worse than it is.
The film looks likely to offend many people.
That book looks interesting.
That looks like an interesting book.
It doesn't look like fun to me.
You made me look a complete fool!
That looks an interesting book.

senses.definition: to have a particular appearance like

examples.x: That photograph doesn't look like her at all.
‘What does your cousin look like?’ ‘He's tall and thin with brown hair.’
You look as though you slept badly.

senses.definition: to seem likely to happen or be true like

examples.x: It looks like rain (= it looks as if it's going to rain).
It doesn't look as if we'll be moving after all.

examples.cf: look to somebody as if…/as though…
examples.x: It looks to me as though the company is in real trouble.
They don’t look like they’re trying to win.
It looks to me like they have a plan.

senses.definition: to face a particular direction

examples.x: The house looks east.
The hotel looks out over the harbour.
The kitchen looks onto the garden.

senses.definition: a bush or tree with dark, smooth, shiny leaves that remain on the bush and stay green through the year

examples.x: a laurel hedge

senses.definition: honour and praise given to somebody because of something that they have achieved

examples.x: She won laurels for her first novel.

senses.definition: having good luck

examples.x: His friend was killed and he knows he is lucky to be alive.
She was lucky enough to be chosen for the team.
You were lucky (that) you spotted the danger in time.
In terms of my career I feel incredibly lucky.
You can think yourself lucky you didn't get mugged.
She counted herself lucky that she still had a job.
Mark is one of the lucky ones—he at least has somewhere to sleep.
the lucky winners
He was among the lucky ones who escaped with only minor injuries.

senses.definition: being the result of good luck

examples.x: It was lucky for us that we were able to go.
Lucky for her, a police car was passing.
It is lucky (that) neither was killed in the accident.
That was the luckiest escape of my life.
a lucky guess
A lucky find on the edge of the Cotswolds is helping archaeologists discover what life was like in Roman Britain.
I had a lucky break when I left school getting a job on local radio.

senses.definition: bringing good luck

examples.x: a lucky charm
The team thinks of me as their lucky mascot.

senses.definition: using clever plans to achieve what you want, without people realizing what you are doing Niccolò Machiavelli

examples.x: Machiavellian manipulation
There were press accusations of Machiavellian deception.

senses.definition: a person who is rich, powerful and successful, especially in business Magnate

examples.x: a media/property/shipping magnate
The company was owned by shipping magnate Fred Olsen.

senses.definition: a time to begin a project, hold a ceremony, etc. that is likely to bring success in the future

examples.x: A mahurat must now be chosen for the wedding.

senses.definition: a ceremony to announce the start of something, especially work on a new film

examples.x: The mahurat was attended by the entire cast and crew.
the mahurat shot (= the first scene filmed)

senses.definition: a person or thing that is the most important part of something and enables it to exist or be successful

examples.x: She is the mainstay of our theatre group.
Cocoa is the country's economic mainstay.

senses.definition: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together wash the dishes

examples.x: to make a table/dress/cake
to make bread/cement/paper
She makes her own clothes.
How do you make that dish with the peppers and olives in it?
made in France (= on a label)
What's your shirt made of?

What's your shirt made out of?
Wine is made from grapes.
The grapes are made into wine.

senses.definition: to write, create or prepare something

examples.x: These regulations were made to protect children.

senses.definition: to cause something to appear as a result of breaking, tearing, hitting or removing material

senses.definition: to cause something to exist, happen or be done make

examples.x: to make a noise/mess/fuss

senses.definition: to cause somebody/something to feel, show or have a particular quality; to cause somebody/something to be or become something

examples.x: The news made him very happy.

Technology continues to make our lives easier.

The full story was never made public.

examples.x: She always makes me laugh.
This dress makes me look fat.
What makes you say that (= why do you think so)?
Nothing will make me change my mind.

senses.definition: a share in something, especially money

examples.x: They were rewarded with a cut of 5% from the profits.

senses.definition: a piece of meat cut from an animal

cheap cuts of stewing lamb

senses.definition: a mark given in an exam or for a piece of school work

examples.x: She got good grades in her exams.

70 per cent of students achieved Grade C or above.

senses.definition: (in the US school system) one of the levels in a school with children of similar age

examples.x: Sam is in (the) second grade.

senses.definition: the quality of a particular product or material

examples.x: All the materials used were of the highest grade.

senses.definition: a level of ability or rank that somebody has in an organization

examples.x: salary/pay grades (= levels of pay)

senses.definition: how serious an illness is

examples.x: low/high grade fever

senses.definition: a slope on a road or railway; the degree to which the ground slopes

examples.x: The hill has a grade of 25 per cent.

senses.definition: a level of exam in musical skill

examples.x: grade 6 piano

senses.definition: a written or printed symbol that is used as a sign of something, for example the quality of something or who made or owns it

examples.x: I put a mark in the margin to remind me to check the figure.
Any piece of silver bearing his mark is extremely valuable.
A faint pencil mark showed where the house was on the map.
Every image is made up of hundreds of brush marks.

senses.definition: a number or letter that is given to show the standard of somebody’s work or performance or is given to somebody for answering something correctly

examples.x: to get a good/poor mark in English

senses.definition: a point given for a correct answer in an exam or competition

examples.x: You get two marks for each correct answer.

‘You're wearing a tie!’ ‘Full marks for observation.’

senses.definition: a small area of dirt, a spot or a cut on a surface that makes it look less good mark

examples.x: The children left dirty marks all over the kitchen floor.
There was a red mark on his arm.
a burn/scratch mark
Detectives found no marks on the body.

senses.definition: a spot or area of colour on the body of a person or an animal that helps you to recognize them patch

examples.x: a horse with a white mark on its head

Look for a bird with a blue mark on its wings.

senses.definition: a sign that a quality or feeling exists

examples.x: On the day of the funeral businesses remained closed as a mark of respect.
Such coolness under pressure is the mark of a champion.

senses.definition: a level or point that something reaches that is thought to be important

examples.x: Unemployment has passed the four million mark.

The needle was flickering around the 80 mark.
She was leading at the halfway mark.

senses.definition: a particular type or model of a machine or vehicle

examples.x: the Mark II engine

senses.definition: a particular level of temperature in a gas oven

examples.x: Preheat the oven to gas Mark 6.

senses.definition: a cross made on a document instead of a signature by somebody who is not able to write their name
a target

examples.x: Of the blows delivered, barely half found their mark.
to hit/miss the mark
Shock tactics often fall wide of their mark (= are not successful).

senses.definition: the former unit of money in Germany (replaced in 2002 by the euro)
to control or be in charge of a business, a team, an organization, land, etc.

examples.x: to manage a business/factory/bank/hotel/soccer team
to manage a department/project
I think that Forestry Tasmania manages the forest.
The school has been badly managed for several years.
We need people who are good at managing.

senses.definition: to succeed in doing something, especially something difficult Can

examples.x: I don't know exactly how we'll manage it, but we will, somehow.
Can you manage another piece of cake? (= eat one)
We managed to get to the airport in time.
How did you manage to persuade him?
She somehow managed to escape through the window.
He always manages to say the wrong thing.
They managed to find a place to stay.
We couldn't have managed without you.
‘Need any help?’ ‘No, thanks. I can manage.’

senses.definition: to succeed in achieving or producing something

examples.x: In spite of his disappointment, he managed a weak smile.
Davies manages light humour without seeming silly.

senses.definition: to be able to solve your problems, deal with a difficult situation, etc.

examples.x: She's 82 and can't manage on her own any more.
How do you manage without a car?
I can manage without a dishwasher.
I don’t know how she manages on her own with four kids.

senses.definition: to be able to live or survive without having much money, support, sleep, etc.

examples.x: young families who are just about managing
She was finding it difficult to manage financially.
He has to manage on less than £100 a week.
Many find it difficult to manage on their weekly income.
He generally managed on five hours' sleep a night.
Everyone will just have to manage with less.

senses.definition: to use money, time, information, etc. in a sensible way

examples.x: Don't tell me how to manage my affairs.
a computer program that helps you manage data efficiently
This enables pension funds to manage risk.

senses.definition: to be able to do something at a particular time

examples.x: Let's meet up again—can you manage next week sometime?

senses.definition: to keep somebody/something under control; to be able to deal with somebody/something

examples.x: It's like trying to manage an unruly child.
Can you manage that suitcase?
She manages horses better than anyone I know.
I really liked the chapter about how to manage stress.

senses.definition: to control how land is used, so that it is used in a sensible way

examples.x: The landowners manage their land to provide habitat for the desired species.
All the timber comes from sustainably managed forests.

senses.definition: the activity of running and controlling a business or similar organization

examples.x: a career in management
hotel/project management
a management training course
the day-to-day management of the business
The report blames bad management.
Effective financial management is essential.

senses.definition: the people who run and control a business or similar organization

examples.x: The management is/are considering closing the factory.

junior/middle/senior management
the bank's/airline's/hospital's management
a management decision/job

My role is to act as a mediator between employees and management.
Most managements are keen to avoid strikes.

senses.definition: the act or skill of dealing with people or situations in a successful way

examples.x: classroom management
a waste management system/company/plan
management of staff/patients/resources
Diet plays an important role in the management of heart disease.

senses.definition: the company that sells the largest quantity of a particular kind of product

examples.x: We are the market leader in e-bikes.

senses.definition: a product that is the most successful of its kind

examples.x: It is the market leader in the laptop market.

senses.definition: a wonderful and surprising person or thing

examples.x: the marvels of nature/technology

senses.definition: wonderful results or things that have been achieved

examples.x: The doctors have done marvels for her.

senses.definition: a detailed plan that is designed to make a complicated project successful

examples.x: He had no master plan in place before he started the project.

senses.definition: something clever that you do that gives a successful result

examples.x: a masterstroke that established his career

senses.definition: an award given to some people in the UK for a special achievement; a person who has received this award (the abbreviation for ‘Member (of the Order) of the British Empire’) honours

examples.x: She was made an MBE in 2023.
Jim Cronin MBE

senses.definition: to measure somebody/something

examples.x: We spent the morning measuring up and deciding where the furniture would go.
We need to measure the room up for a new carpet.

senses.definition: achieving success very quickly

examples.x: a meteoric rise to fame
a meteoric career

senses.definition: relating to meteors

examples.x: meteoric craters

senses.definition: done or produced because of something successful that somebody else has done

examples.x: The magazine ‘Hello!’ gave rise to a number of me-too publications.

senses.definition: the ability and determination to do something successfully despite difficult conditions metal

examples.x: The next game will be a real test of their mettle.
She really showed her mettle under pressure.

senses.definition: the ability to make a financial success of everything you do

examples.x: a businessman with the Midas touch

senses.definition: an important official job that a person or group of people is given to do, especially when they are sent to another country

examples.x: She led a recent trade mission to China.
Thomas More toured Antwerp on a diplomatic mission for the king.
It was too late to launch a rescue mission.
They undertook a fact-finding mission in the region.
a mercy mission to aid homeless refugees

senses.definition: a group of people doing such a job; the place where they work

examples.x: He is the head of the British mission in Berlin.

senses.definition: the work of teaching people about Christianity, especially in a foreign country; a group of people doing such work

examples.x: Gandhi’s attitude to mission and conversion
a Catholic mission in Africa
She took up a position as a school teacher at St Peter's mission in Montana.

senses.definition: a building or group of buildings used by a Christian mission
particular work that you feel it is your duty to do

examples.x: Her mission in life was to work with homeless people.
We are committed to the mission of helping students realize their full potential.
You can tell by the determined way he talks that he is a man with a mission.

senses.definition: an important job that is done by a soldier, group of soldiers, etc. declare/​make/​wage

examples.x: The squadron flew on a reconnaissance mission.
The military are fulfilling an important peacekeeping mission.

senses.definition: a flight into space

examples.x: a US space mission
He's been on several shuttle missions over the last decade.

senses.definition: a task or journey that is very difficult and takes a long time to complete

examples.x: It's a mission to get there.

senses.definition: a situation in which your ideas or principles are proved to be right and fair, even though you may not have succeeded where practical results are considered

examples.x: In spite of the result, we felt we had won a moral victory.

senses.definition: to change position or make somebody/something change position in a way that can be seen, heard or felt

examples.x: Don't move—stay perfectly still.
The bus was already moving when I jumped onto it.
The ball was really moving (= moving fast) when it reached him.
He could hear someone moving around in the room above.
Phil moved towards the window.
You can hardly move in this pub on Saturdays (= because it is so crowded).
You can't move for books in her room.
Temperatures will drop as the cold front moves down across France.
I can't move my fingers.
We moved our chairs a little nearer.
She moved the ball toward the opponent's goal.
He moved his arm away from his face.

senses.definition: to change the place where you live, have your work, etc.

examples.x: We don't like it here so we've decided to move.
The company's moving to Scotland.
People move from place to place today in ever greater numbers.
She's been all on her own since her daughter moved away.
We moved house last week.

senses.definition: to make somebody change from one job, class, etc. to another

examples.x: I'm being moved to the New York office.

senses.definition: to change the position of a piece

examples.x: It's your turn to move.
She moved her queen.

senses.definition: to leave, begin something, etc. quickly

examples.x: Let's move—it's time we went shopping.

senses.definition: to change; to change something

examples.x: The government has not moved on this issue.
Things have moved on a lot since the days when I was young.
Let's move the meeting to Wednesday.

senses.definition: to make progress in the way or direction mentioned

examples.x: Time is moving on.
Share prices moved ahead today.
After that, things moved forward at lightning speed
Things are not moving as fast as we hoped.
Things certainly move fast in the blogosphere.
Finally things are moving in the right direction.

senses.definition: to take action; to do something action

examples.x: The police moved quickly to dispel the rumours.
The firm has moved to reassure customers that they will continue to provide good service.

senses.definition: to cause somebody to have strong feelings, especially of sympathy or of being sad

examples.x: We were deeply moved by her plight.
Grown men were moved to tears at the horrific scenes.

senses.definition: to cause somebody to do something

senses.definition: the power of pleasing or attracting people

senses.definition: a feature or quality that is pleasant or attractive

senses.definition: a small object worn on a chain or bracelet that is believed to bring good luck

senses.definition: an act or words believed to have magic power

examples.x: He hasn't said he'll do it yet, but I'm working on him.

senses.definition: to train the body by physical exercise

examples.x: I work out regularly to keep fit.

senses.definition: to develop in a successful way

senses.definition: an act or event that does not follow the laws of nature and is believed to be caused by God

senses.definition: to try to reach or achieve a goal

senses.definition: a great success

a special quality, especially one that is essential for success and is difficult to describe

senses.definition: a person, either male or female

senses.definition: humans from a particular period of history Man
